text: in the last few minutes Theresa May has
given an update about brexit discussions
with the European Union
speaking on the second day of the summit
in Brussels mrs. May said she was
positive about what the negotiations had
achieved so far earlier at the head of
the European Council Donald Tusk
said EU leaders would begin to prepare
for talks about a trade deal with the UK
the Prime Minister acknowledged a lot
more was still she said there was still
some way to go I am ambitious and
positive for Britain's future and for
these negotiations but I know we still
have some way to go both sides have
approached these talks with
professionalism and a constructive
spirit and we should recognize what has
been achieved to date the UK and the EU
share the same objective of safeguarding
the rights of EU nationals living in the
UK and UK nationals living in the EU EU
citizens have made a huge contribution
to our country and let me be clear that
whatever happens we want them and their
families to stay while there are a small
number of issues that remain outstanding
on citizens rights I'm confident that we
are in touching distance of a deal on
Northern Ireland we've agreed that the
Belfast agreement must be at the heart
of our approach and that Northern
Ireland's unique circumstances demands
specific solutions it is vital that
joint work on the peace process is not
affected in any way it is too important
for that and both sides agree that there
cannot be any physical infrastructure at
the border and that the common travel
area must continue we have both
committed to delivering a flexible and
imaginative approach on this vital issue
this council is an important moment it
is a point at which to assess and
reflect on how to make further progress
my speech in Florence made two important
steps which have added a new impetus to
the negotiations I gave a firm
commitment on the financial settlement
and I proposed a time-limited
implementation period based on current
terms which is in the interest of both
the UK and the EU both sides agreed that
subsequent rounds
have been conducted in a new spirit my
fellow leaders have been discussing this
this morning and I believe that it is in
the interests of the UK that the eu-27
continues to take a united approach but
if we are going to take a step forward
together it must be on the basis of
joint effort and endeavor we must work
together to get to an outcome that we
can stand behind and that works for all
our people Theresa May speaking in the
last few moments in Brussels well in a
moment we'll talk to our political
correspondent Alex Forsyth who's in
Westminster force this morning but first
to Brussels and Adam Fleming is there
for us Adam what is the feeling on the
ground about how this summit has gone
for to resume
well the EU leaders of the other
twenty-seven remaining countries seem to
have gone out of their way to help to
resume at this summit to accentuate the
positive eliminate the negative when it
comes to the brexit process
think back to yesterday when the Prime
Minister first got here and she did that
long walk from the front door to the
summit room the whole way she was
accompanied by Emmanuel macron and
Angela Merkel gone the images of Teresa
May standing by herself at her chair at
the summit table with no one talking to
her that's the first thing Angela
Merkel's press conference in the middle
of the night last night at the end of
the first day of talks saying that okay
there wasn't progress on the first phase
of talk sufficient progress to move to
phase 2 of the talks yet but they were
happening a constructive atmosphere and
that the British media was
misrepresenting how well that they were
going and that phase 2 could be on the
way and then look at the summit
conclusions that were adopted by the 27
EU leaders in the meeting they've just
been having separately while Teresa May
was doing her news conference it took
them 90 seconds to adopt their
conclusions which will open the way for
them to start preparing internally for
trade talks and talks about the future
relationship between the UK and the EU
that is the aspect that the European
Council President Donald Tusk chose to
tweet about after that 90 seconds of
discussions that they had on that he
didn't tweak to say no sufficient
progress has been made
he didn't tweak to say UK needs to go
much further in the bragg's at negotiate
to meet us and meet our demands who
tweeted that he wants to start getting
ready for Phase two of the Bragg's at
talks so as I said European leaders
basically going out of their way to make
the brexit process look like it's going
well not that it's going badly and it'll
be interesting Adam to see if further
news conferences that were expecting
there this morning mirror the sort of
language that Teresa may has been using
in the last few minutes you know she was
talking about standing alongside the EU
as a partner our continent shared
objectives that sort of language yes so
I know for a fact that the British
delegation have been in touch with other
countries in the run-up to this summit
to create this positive atmosphere and
moments like the macro Morocco may
moment that look kind of accidental and
just an accident of timing but are
actually carefully planned so it will be
intriguing to see yes the phrases and
the notes that other leaders strike
although when the leaders were arriving
for their summit this morning for day
two on the red carpet you heard people
like the prime minister of Malta Joseph
Muscat saying that last night to resume
gave her best performance ever at an EU
summit that she was more candid and a
better performer that than she had been
before but then you get people like the
president of Lithuania saying yeah
rhetoric is one thing they still want
detailed commitments on the actual
technical brexit negotiations which
brings us to what the big stumbling
block is at the moment the big blockage
is about the UK's financial obligations
the EU wants to agree a methodology for
calculating how much money the UK owes
the EU for commitments that signed up to
while it was a member and you'll notice
in the press conference Theresa May was
asked by our colleague Laura Koons Berg
if she would deny reports which have
been swirling around this press room
this morning that it privately Teresa
may has told you leaders she is prepared
to give them more money than was implied
in the Florence speech now the Prime
Minister would say I imagine and her
advisers would say that the Florence
speech was very carefully worded it
offered to say that the UK would make
financial contributions for the next two
years of the EU budget so no-one would
be out of pocket but she also talks
about living
to financial obligations so she's made
the message what leaders know what is
the detail of what what she's actually
prepared to pay for okay Adam thank you
very much
